citations.narrative:
The facility is allowing the public to hold an adult sloth. The sloth could easily bite someone on the neck with the way it is
held. Sloths have the potential to inflict serious bites that can become easily infected and/or serious scratches with their
long claws if they become agitated or scared. There is also the potential for the sloth to become injured if a child or adult
accidentally drops the animal.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public. The
facility needs to discontinue allowing the public to hold the sloth.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023

The facility is allowing the public to feed the giraffe without an attendant present. The facility offers overnight
accommodation in suites attached to the giraffe barn. Two of these suites have small windows the guests can open and
feed the giraffe at any time without an attendant present. The facility does provide food appropriate for the giraffe but
without an attendant, the facility cannot confirm the giraffe is not being offered food that could be harmful to his health.
The giraffe can only be fed by the public when an attendant is present.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023

The facility is allowing primates that are not under direct control of an experienced handler to sit on the head and
shoulders of visitors.
Nonhuman primates used in uncaged public exhibits must be under the direct control and supervision of an experienced
handler or trainer at all times when the public is present.
Direct control involves the primate responding immediately to voice commands. If they are not trained to voice
commands, then a tether should be used.
Even under direct control, primates should not be allowed on the heads and shoulders of visitors. Primates can easily bite
or scratch an eye, nose, ear, or neck before a person can consciously respond to control them.
The facility needs to establish a method of direct control for the primates and discontinue allowing them on heads and
shoulders of visitors.
To be corrected by: July 24, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
